key_points: The Capitol riot is described as a result of years of hateful rhetoric, stoked by disinformation and conspiracy theories.
Experts on far-right extremism see the event as a natural outcome of the violence and extremism promoted online.
Members of far-right groups, including Proud Boys and white supremacist groups, were part of the riot.
Online forums used by Trump supporters celebrated the chaos at the Capitol.
The riot included figures and groups known for spreading conspiracy theories like QAnon.
Social media platforms were working to remove threats and calls for violence following the event.
The phrase 'civil war' and 'storm the capitol' surged in online mentions according to Zignal Labs.
The ADL's vice president stated the riot was the 'logical conclusion to extremism and hate going unchecked'.
Proud Boys leader Henry 'Enrique' Tarrio was arrested prior to the riot and ordered to stay out of Washington.
ADL's CEO called the event 'a dark day for democracy' and urged for Trump's social media suspension, which Twitter partially enforced.
spokespersons: Amy Spitalnick (Executive Director, Integrity First for America)
Oren Segal (Vice President of the ADL's Center on Extremism)
